snippet: More than a dozen states will use the laws for the first time in a presidential election this fall, a step researchers say disproportionately affects minority voters.
abstract: Research shows voter identification laws, subject of aggressive debate across nation, restrict voter turnout and disproportionately affect minority voting, not by having people turned away at polls but by convincing many qualified voters not to even try to vote; nearly three dozen states have such laws, and 17 of those require photo ID; laws are influencing how 2016 campaigns are run, as more than dozen states plan to use voter ID laws for first time in presidential election.

byline.original: By MICHAEL WINES and MANNY FERNANDEZ
byline.contributor: Susan Beachy and Alain Delaquérière contributed research.

lead_paragraph: More than a dozen states will use the laws for the first time in a presidential election this fall, a step researchers say disproportionately affects minority voters.

headline.main: Stricter Rules for Voter IDs Reshape Races
headline.print_headline: Stricter Rules Over Voter IDs Reshape Races
